results.title: Bush Mechanics car replica
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly and Thomas Rice
results.credit_line: Produced by Rebel Films and commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Steel, aluminium, plastic, Mulga branch, fencing wire, automotive paint, acrylic paint

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

results.description:
David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) only ran for one season, but it became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on the red-sand roads of outback Australia. The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.
description_for_label:

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this latest action-packed video by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

Displayed in the gallery in a massive three-channel video installation, the work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Director: Reko Rennie

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

Produced by Trials

Director of Photography: Sherwin Akbarzadeh

Featuring

Sensei Master: Adam Briggs (Yorta Yorta)

Students: Caine Muir (Yorta Yorta and Wati Wati), Inala Cooper (Yawuru), James Saunders (Gundtijmara and Wiradjuri), Joe Bell (Yorta Yorta), Kelvin Onus King (Gunditjmara), Kimmie Lovegrove (Ngarrindjeri), Mila Rennie Galvin (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay),Reko Rennie (Kamilaroi/Gamilaroi/Gamilaraay), Sermsah Pepi Bin Saad (Nyikina), Shane Mankitya Cook (Guwa (Koa) and Wulli Wulli), Talahiva Rose (Gomeroi), Vicky Frowd (Wiradjuri)

results.title:
Radio Rythm, No. A9-1-2A
Vitaphone record
results.brief_description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.
results.description: Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.
